questionListItems.title: I was charged more than the capped rates for the Pioneer/Merdeka Generation card holders. What can I do?

answer.body:
If you went to a CHAS GP clinic for your vaccination, please approach the clinic directly to enquire about your charges.

If you are unable to resolve this issue with the CHAS GP clinic directly, you can call AIC CHAS hotline (1800-275-2427) or fill in the form at https://www.chas.sg/contact-us/clinic-or-claim-feedback.

questionListItems.title: My CHAS GP clinic is already part of the TF-HPV Immunisation Programme. What do I have to do?

answer.body:
HAS clinics participating in this programme will be auto-enrolled as offering the HPV2 on their appointment system in order to reduce administrative work. There is an option to “opt out” of offering the HPV2 on the HAS Admin portal.

Note: Offering HPV2 on HAS does not automatically qualify your clinic for the Temasek Foundation HPV Immunisation Programme to offer HPV2 at no cost. You will need to separately register by submitting this form.

CHAS GP Clinics that are already on this programme do not have to register again.

questionListItems.title: What are some rare but serious side-effects that I need to seek medical advice immediately?

answer.body:
Severe allergic reactions (anaphylaxis) are rare and can happen within minutes to a few hours after vaccination.

The symptoms of a severe allergic reaction include one or more of the following:

  • Swollen face/eyes/lips/tongue

  • Difficulty in breathing

  • Itchy skin rashes over your whole body

If you experience any of these symptoms, you should inform your healthcare professional immediately.



Disclaimers

If you took more than the recommended dose, please seek medical advice immediately. The information provided on this page does not replace information from your healthcare professional. Please consult your healthcare professional for more information.

questionListItems.title: What are the types of HPV vaccines available in Singapore?

answer.body:
The two HPV vaccines that are available are HPV2 (Cervarix) and HPV9 (Gardasil 9). Subsidies are only available for HPV2 (Cervarix).

HPV2 (Cervarix) provides protection against HPV types 16 and 18, which account for 70% of all cervical cancers, and have been shown to be both clinically- and cost-effective in the local setting. It is registered for use for females.

HPV9 vaccination (Gardasil 9) provides protection against an additional 20% of cancer-causing HPV types. It is registered for use for both females and males.

Subsidies are not available for HPV9 (Gardasil 9).

Please confirm with your doctor on the type of HPV vaccination that you wish to receive prior when making the appointment. At present, only HPV2 (Cervarix) can be booked through the Health Appointment System.

questionListItems.title: What is the flu vaccine used for?

answer.body:
Flu vaccines help to prevent infection from flu and complications resulting from it. 

Complications from flu infection include  infection of the lungs (pneumonia), ear (otitis media), brain (meningitis), blood (bacteremia) and other serious infections.

questionListItems.title: What is the pneumococcal vaccine used for?

answer.body:
Pneumococcal vaccines help to prevent pneumococcal disease caused by the bacteria Streptococcus pneumoniae. 

Pneumococcal disease includes infection of the lungs (pneumonia), ear (otitis media), brain (meningitis), blood (bacteremia) and other serious infections.

Symptoms of pneumococcal disease vary depending on the infected organ. It can range from low-grade fever, cough, earache and chest pain, to more serious symptoms such as confusion or severe headaches.

questionListItems.title: What precautions should I follow before receiving the flu vaccine?

answer.body:
Inform your healthcare professional if:

- You are allergic to this vaccine or any of the other ingredients of this vaccine
- You have a history of Guillain-Barr Syndrome (a rare nerve condition)
- You are pregnant or breastfeeding

questionListItems.title: What precautions should I follow before receiving the pneumococcal vaccine?

answer.body:
Inform your healthcare professional if:

  • You are allergic to this vaccine or any of the other ingredients of this vaccine

  • You have a history of Guillain-Barré Syndrome (a rare nerve condition)

  • You are pregnant or breastfeeding

questionListItems.title: Where can I find the full list of CHAS GPs that offer subsidised vaccinations?

answer.body:
The full list of CHAS GPs can be found (here) . 
Please call beforehand to ensure that the clinic offers the type of vaccine that you are looking for.

questionListItems.title: Who is eligible for subsidies for HPV2 vaccination?

answer.body:
Female Singapore citizens aged 9 - 26 are eligible for subsidies at CHAS GP clinics.

Female Permanent Residents (PRs) aged 9 -26 may receive their vaccinations at CHAS clinics or polyclinics but are eligible for subsidies only at polyclinics.

Both Singapore Citizen and PR females aged 9 – 26 years can use MediSave to cover the out-of-pocket costs at both locations.

questionListItems.title: Who should receive the HPV vaccination?

answer.body: In Singapore, according to the National Childhood Immunisation Schedule and National Adult Immunisation Schedule, HPV vaccination is recommended for females aged 9 to 26 years.
